author: Times of Malta
title: Indian Catholic society in Malta marks second anniversary
text:
A society for Indian Roman Catholics in Malta – St Paul’s Latin Community – recently held a commemorative event to mark the second anniversary of its foundation at Alleluia Hall, next to the Franciscan conventual friary in St Paul’s Bay.
The community’s founder and priest in charge, Fr Damian Veliyil, welcomed the participants, and Mass was concelebrated by Mgr Dennis Kuruppassery, first counsellor to the Apostolic Nuncio, Fr Paul Punnackal George, priest in charge of the Orthodox Syrian church, and Fr Veliyil.
The principal guest was Fr Colin Sammut, OFM Conv., provincial of the Franciscan Conventual Community, who was adorned with a traditional Indian shawl to the community’s gratitude to him. Other guests adorned with the traditional shawl included Fr Joseph Mamo, OFM Conv., parish priest of Our Lady of Sorrows parish in St Paul’s Bay, Mgr Kuruppassery, Fr George, and other Franciscan Maltese and Indian friars.
Afterwards a video was presented about the journey of the community over the past two years, an Instagram page was inaugurated, prizes were distributed and a cultural programme was held, which included traditional singing and dancing from Kerala State.
St Paul’s Latin Community president Christopher Nelson delivered a short concluding speech thanking everyone working towards the community’s wellbeing. This was followed by lunch of Indian food.
Independent journalism costs money. Support Times of Malta for the price of a coffee.

author: @infobae
title: Agredieron a un conocido youtuber libertario afuera del Congreso y Milei repudió el episodio - Infobae
text:
Mariano Pérez cubría la jornada de debate en Diputados cuando fue atacado por un grupo de manifestantes Un youtuber libertario que cubría la sesión de este jueves en la Cámara de Diputados fue agredido en las inmediaciones del Congreso de la Nación por un grupo de manifestantes que protestaba en contra de la Ley Bases. El episodio ocurrió en horas de la tarde y provocó el repudio del presidente Javier Milei, que hizo un descargo al respecto en sus redes sociales.
La víctima del ataque fue Mariano Pérez , un joven periodista que se encontraba en las afueras del Parlamento mostrando, a través de una transmisión en vivo, la concentración que se desarrollaba en la calle mientras los legisladores trataban el proyecto oficialista en el recinto.
Fue durante una entrevista a uno de los presentes en la manifestación que al menos dos hombres comenzaron a empujar a su colaborador, que estaba grabando el reportaje. En consecuencia, el youtuber interrumpió la conversación con su entrevistado e intentó separar a los agresores de su compañero.
Al mismo tiempo, otra persona se puso detrás del joven y empezó a empujarlo con el objetivo de moverlo de la zona donde estaba haciendo las notas. En la misma secuencia, que quedó grabada en un video que Pérez luego difundió en sus redes, se ve cómo uno de los atacantes también intentó sacarle el celular.
”Eh, no, con el teléfono no eh”, se escucha que le dice el periodista al presunto ladrón mientras el grupo de manifestantes, ya más nutrido que al principio, continuaba empujándolo para sacarlo de la protesta. Algunos de ellos, de acuerdo a lo registrado en la filmación, hasta se le acercaron con intención de golpearlo.
El tuit de Javier Milei sobre la agresión al periodista liberal El youtuber y su camarógrafo lograron salir de la concentración con la ayuda de uno de los piqueteros que se acercó a ellos y los escoltó por varios metros hasta que se alejaron del lugar. Cuando ya estaban a una distancia de aproximadamente una cuadra, este volvió a la protesta y dejó al periodista, que seguía grabando.
La filmación de lo ocurrido la compartió luego en sus redes sociales. “No solo me pegaron de a muchos, sino que además son unos CHORROS que me quisieron robar mi celular. Nunca mejor representados los zurdos. Van a tener que MATARME si quieren que deje de hacer periodismo”, escribió el joven en su cuenta de X.
El video llegó al presidente Javier Milei, quien se hizo eco de la agresión y la repudió con un contundente mensaje. “Inaceptable” , calificó el jefe de Estado el accionar desarrollado afuera del Congreso.
Y agregó: “Aquí tenés una muestra de aquellos que se oponen a nuestras reformas. Tal como siempre ocurre, cuando nos acusan de cosas horribles no es ni más ni menos que su proyección. Viva la libertad carajo”.
Mariano Pérez, el youtuber atacado A las palabras del mandatario se sumaron otros dirigentes liberales que también compartieron la grabación en sus redes sociales e hicieron un posteo al respeto.
Una de ellas fue la diputada libertaria Marcela Pagano: “Repudio absolutamente todo acto de violencia física contra trabajadores de prensa. Es inadmisible que haya personas que se sientan dueñas de la calle y ajenas a la ley. Libertad de expresión SIEMPRE. Toda mi solidaridad con Mariano Pérez y equipo”, publicó sobre el episodio.
Ramiro Marra, por su parte, tuiteó: “Siempre y en todo lugar, la izquierda usa la violencia física para imponer su discurso”.
La agresión contra el periodista libertario ocurrió en pleno tratamiento de la Ley Bases y el Paquete Fiscal en la Cámara de Diputados, que desde el mediodía de este jueves debaten la iniciativa oficialista en el recinto tras los cambios que introdujo el Senado. El debate contará con 200 expositores y podría extenderse durante 12 horas, antes de la votación.

author: Vid Karmarkar
title: The silent victims of cancer: unravelling the indirect consequences on children - The Hindu
text:
“Why me, Ma?” Aarav, an 18-year-old from Mumbai, asked when he was diagnosed with Hodgkin’s Lymphoma in 2018. His dream of becoming an investment banker had shattered with the diagnosis. But he didn’t just survive - he thrived. I heard him speak at an event organised by a leading cancer hospital in Mumbai for International Childhood Cancer Day, which falls on February 15.
Unlike most teenagers of his age, whose hands are busy scrolling through social media, while one of Aarav’s hands received chemotherapy, the other clutched his accountancy books. He didn’t let cancer slow him down. Instead, he conquered it -- emerging as an All India topper in the Chartered Accountancy exams. But not all childhood cancer stories see a happy end.
Aarav reminded me of Meena, a 10-year-old from Pune, whose story took a different turn. Her mother, a domestic help, was diagnosed with late-stage breast cancer. Her father, an autorickshaw driver, worked hard to ensure Meena got an education, believing it was her path to a better future. But cancer rewrote their fate. Her mother could no longer work, and her father, needing to care for her, lost days of income. With their paltry earnings dwindling further, they had no choice but to pull Meena out of school. Unlike Aarav, she wasn’t lucky - cancer didn’t just take her mother’s life; it trapped Meena in a cycle of generational poverty.
A recent National Cancer Registry Programme (NCRP) report found that childhood cancers (0-14 years) account for 4% of all cancer cases in India, while adult cases near a million annually - and these numbers are expected to rise. This leaves lakhs of children vulnerable to the hidden financial toll of cancer. Whether battling the disease or affected by a parent’s illness, children are the silent victims.
Gender disparities in childhood cancer treatment on the decline, doctors call for more awareness, early diagnosis Protecting the next generation Children are the future of a nation. To build a strong nation, we need an educated and skilled workforce. Education is also a pathway to their economic empowerment. But cancer disrupts this journey.
When a child or parent is diagnosed with cancer, schooling takes a hit. Low-income families are often forced to pull children out due to financial strain, while older siblings in such households take on caregiving or work to supplement income, limiting their future prospects.
For instance, Sridevi, a second-year college student from a low-income family from Hyderabad, had to work as a fast-food crew member and tutor school children to cover her father’s escalating oral cancer treatment costs. This impacted her academic performance and took a toll on her mental health.
Disruptions in education have a cascading effect. Studies show that children who drop out of school due to financial distress face lower lifetime earnings and higher rates of economic instability. In the context of cancer, the disease not only devastates the present generation but also risks trapping the next generation in a cycle of hardship.
Free cancer care alone won’t help India fight cancer | Explained The other indirect costs of cancer treatment Loss of opportunity for education is just one example of the indirect costs of cancer treatment. Such costs includes non-medical expenses and financial losses from diagnosis and treatment. These can be as debilitating as direct medical and non-medical costs.
Loss of income is one of the most significant burdens, as patients may need extended leave or even lose their jobs. Family caregivers, often spouses or children, may also reduce work hours or quit jobs entirely, worsening financial strain.
Travel and accommodation costs add to the burden, especially for patients from rural areas who must frequently travel to treatment centers in cities. Daily living expenses rise due to special diets, hospital visits, and caregiving demands, often requiring household help or costly services.
The psychosocial and mental health impact further escalates the strain, with many patients and caregivers needing counseling or therapy, which is often unaffordable.
Why does cancer get diagnosed late in India? And does having a government health insurance card help with faster treatment? The role of insurance and government schemes Government-backed health insurance programmes like Ayushman Bharat Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (AB-PMJAY) have played a crucial role in reducing direct medical costs for cancer patients in India. These schemes provide financial coverage for inpatient costs, alleviating the immediate financial stress on affected families. But the indirect costs of treatment are insufficiently addressed.
Disability riders in insurance plans provide crucial financial support for cancer patients facing long-term disability. Many Indian insurers offer term plans with these riders, covering severe accidents and major cancers like breast, lung, and liver cancer. They provide income replacement or lump-sum payouts to offset lost wages, caregiving costs, and daily expenses. However, they are often excluded from standard policies, have strict eligibility criteria, or come with high premiums, limiting access for those who need them most.
To ease non-medical expenses, Indian Railways and Air India are offering discounted fares for patients and caregivers, while Himachal Pradesh and Haryana provide free bus travel for cancer patients. Additionally, monthly pension schemes in states like Haryana, Tripura, and Himachal Pradesh are helping mitigate the financial burden of indirect cancer costs.
The way forward While policies focus on reducing direct treatment costs, easing the indirect burden - through caregiver aid, educational support, and employment protections - is equally crucial. These interventions improve treatment adherence, mental well-being, and safeguard the next generation’s opportunities.
Ensuring equitable education for cancer-affected families requires empathetic, multi-level action - from government policies and CSR funding to state income support and school-level interventions. Recognising that cancer brings not just medical but financial and emotional distress, policies must address these broader challenges. Simple yet impactful measures - use of calculators, extra coaching, extended deadlines, free school meals, and mental health support - can make education more inclusive. By integrating such interventions, we can prevent cancer from becoming a lifelong barrier to economic and educational equity.
(Dr. Vid Karmarkar is the Founder of Canseva Foundation. vid.karmarkar@gmail.com)
Published - February 21, 2025 05:00 am IST
Read Comments Copy link Email Facebook Twitter Telegram LinkedIn WhatsApp Reddit READ LATER PRINT

author: Belga Belga
title: Pyongyang qualifie d'"imprudente" la vente d'hélicoptères américains à Séoul
text:
Pyongyang qualifie d'"imprudente" la vente d'hélicoptères américains à Séoul
La Corée du Nord a qualifié jeudi d'acte "imprudent et provocant" la vente par les Américains d'hélicoptères Apache à la Corée du Sud, affirmant qu'elle y répondrait par un renforcement de son propre arsenal.
- Publié le 23-08-2024 à 02h24
- à Séoul, Corée du Sud
"Il s'agit d'un acte imprudent et provocant" qui vise à "délibérément augmenter l'instabilité sécuritaire dans la région", a fustigé dans un communiqué le ministère de la Défense nord-coréen.

author: Shreya Mukherjee
title: Rakhi Sawant isn't marrying Pakistani police officer after all
text:
Next Article
Rakhi Sawant isn't marrying Pakistani police officer after all
What's the story
In a shocking turn of events, Pakistani actor-businessman Dodi Khan has publicly announced his decision not to marry Indian reality TV star Rakhi Sawant.
The announcement was made through an Instagram video on Thursday night, leaving Sawant visibly upset. She replied to the video with tearful and broken-heart emojis in the comments section.
This unexpected development has sparked a wave of reactions from fans who were disappointed over Khan's decision.
Video clarification
Khan's video message explained his decision
In the video, Khan, who is also a police officer, clarified that even though he proposed marriage to Sawant, they would not be getting married. He praised Sawant for her resilience in facing life's challenges and expressed admiration for her bravery.
"Hello India and Pakistan, this is Dodi Khan. A few days ago, on social media, you saw a video of mine in which I had proposed Rakhi Sawant," he began his message.
Khan's statement
This is why Khan originally proposed marriage to her
Khan continued, "I proposed her because I know her very well. When I started knowing her, I felt she is a person who loves god a lot. She has seen a lot of ups and downs in her life, she lost her parents but was with them when they were ill."
"A guy came in her life, you all know what he did to her. She has come out of a lot of trauma. She accepted Islam, went for Umrah, and changed her name to Fatima."
Future promise
Khan couldn't take criticism; still promised Sawant future in Pakistan
However, numerous messages and videos criticizing his proposal move forced Khan to change his decision.
Despite calling off the wedding, Khan assured Sawant that she would still become a daughter-in-law of Pakistan.
"I will make you get married to one of my brothers," he promised.
This statement adds another twist to the ongoing saga between Sawant and Khan.
Past relationships
Sawant's love life: A history of high-profile relationships
Sawant's love life has always piqued public interest, with her high-profile relationships and controversies.
She was earlier married to Adil Khan Durrani in 2023 and Ritesh Raj Singh before him.
Despite the drama of her past marriages, Sawant had remained optimistic about her relationship with Khan.
Speaking to News18 Showsha, she had confirmed her new romance, saying, "He is my love. We love each other."

author: Canadian Press
title: B.C. First Nation, Catholic Church announce 'Sacred Covenant' to be signed on Easter
text:
KAMLOOPS, B.C. — Vancouver's Catholic archdiocese is marking Easter with a commitment towards reconciliation with First Nations in B.C., Archbishop J. Michael Miller says.
The church and the chief of the Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc announced Thursday that a "Sacred Covenant" agreement has been reached between the church and the First Nation in Kamloops, B.C.
The covenant comes three years after the First Nation in Kamloops, B.C., announced the discovery of what it believed were the remains of more than 200 children at the site of a former residential school.
Miller said the agreement with the Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc will open a "new chapter" in the relationship between the church and First Nations in B.C.
"Unquestionably, the church was wrong in implementing a government colonialist policy which resulted in devastation for many children, families and communities. We recognize as Catholics, as the Catholic Church, our part in the resulting tragedies," Miller said.
The covenant is set to be signed on Easter Sunday, "a special time of hope and renewal," Miller said.
"Easter Sunday is the ideal time to help start a new chapter in First Nation and Catholic relations in our province," he said. "Our hope and our prayer is that by taking this next step, we will build on our relationship, a relationship already established but still young, and be an example to Canadian society of respecting the identity and the experience of Indigenous Peoples."
Chief Rosanne Casimir of Tk'emlúps te Secwépemc said the covenant will see the church share records and information as the nation continues to investigate the site of a former Kamloops Indian Residential School where hundreds of children went missing.
Casimir said the agreement is crucial to learning the truth about what happened to the missing children, and access to the church's historical records will help "bring justice to the children who never made it home."
"We seek to memorialize the missing children. We also seek meaningful ways to support survivors and intergenerational survivors on their healing journey so that they and their future generations may thrive," she said.
The nation announced in May 2021 that a search around the former school site using ground-penetrating radar found 200 potential unmarked burial sites.
Since then, First Nations across the country have conducted searches and made similar discoveries.
The Truth and Reconciliation Commission identified at least 6,000 deaths at residential schools during their time in operation in Canada between the late 1800s and 1996.
In many of the deaths, schools didn’t record the children's names, genders or cause of death.
The children in the schools were separated from their families and forbidden to speak their own language. They were undernourished and often experienced physical and sexual abuse.
The agreement includes commitments from the church on how to properly memorialize residential school survivors, information sharing about missing children and offering "healing services" to family members of those who attended the school.
Casimir said the possible excavation of the Kamloops school site has not begun as it's a "very sensitive step moving forward," that involves work with other nations, survivors and their families.
This report by The Canadian Press was first published March 28, 2024.
The Canadian Press

title: 油菜花海盛放-新闻中心-温州网
text:
油菜花海盛放
2025-03-13 08:12:00
温州网讯 近日，位于龙湾区的东篱下生态休闲农庄内，油菜花迎风盛放，连绵起伏的金黄花海勾勒出一幅灵动的田园画卷，吸引众多市民游客踏青赏花。
供稿: 温州日报
原标题：油菜花海盛放

author: Chris Tomasson chris.tomasson@gazette.com
title: Quarterback Russell Wilson unlikely to be back with the Broncos in 2024 after 'one of the biggest missteps' in NFL history | Denver Broncos | denvergazette.com
text: The next time Broncos quarterback Russell Wilson grants an interview he might be with a different team. Asked by The Denver Gazette on Thursday if he had anything to say about having been benched in favor of Jarrett Stidham for Sunday’s game against the Los Angeles Chargers, Wilson politely declined. When asked if he might speak to the media before the end of the season, he said he didn’t know. Head coach Sean Payton announced Wednesday that Wilson will be the backup quarterback for the home finale at Empower Field at Mile High. Stidham presumably also will be the starter for the Broncos (7-8), who are all but out of the playoff race, for the Jan. 6 or 7 regular-season finale at Las Vegas. “Russ is still my dawg,’’ running back Javonte Williams said Thursday. “I’m always going to support him and I mean it’s just the league. It is what it is. I know he’ll be all right and I trust the coaches.” The belief by many is Wilson won’t be back next season with the Broncos. He has a $37 million contract guarantee for 2025 that would be invoked if he is still on the roster March 17, the fifth day of the new league year. A source confirmed Wilson was asked by the Broncos during their bye week after an Oct. 29 game against Kansas City if he would be willing to eliminate that guarantee of $37 million for the increased possibility of remaining with the team in 2024 but he declined to do that. “A bunch of people have been saying it was broached back in October,’’ said salary-cap analyst Jason Fitzgerald, who runs the website [OvertheCap.com](http://OvertheCap.com). “I thought Wilson might waive that guarantee to stay on the field in 2024 (with Denver). I can’t imagine he would do something now to benefit the Broncos and help them with the salary cap, so I think they will release him.” The cap consequences of releasing Wilson, 35, would be enormous but guaranteeing Wilson $37 million for 2025 now seems to be off the table. The Broncos, even without Wilson as their quarterback for the next two seasons, would incur $85 million of dead money. As explained by Fitzgerald, Wilson already is on the books for 2024 for a guaranteed $17 million base salary with a $22 million option bonus, which means he is guaranteed $39 million for the season. If the Broncos release Wilson, he likely would be given a post-June 1 designation and Denver would incur dead money on the cap of $53 million in 2024 and $32 million in 2025. The money in addition to the $39 million that still would be on the cap would be remaining prorated amounts on signing bonuses Wilson got of $50 million in 2022 and $20 million for 2023. Wilson had a base salary of $7 million in 2022 and his base number this season is $8 million. Wilson, who made nine Pro Bowls in 10 Seattle seasons and led the Seahawks to a Super Bowl win in his second season of 2013, was traded to Denver in March 2022 for a bevy of players and draft picks, including two in the first round and two in the second round. The Broncos then signed him to a five-year, $245 contract extension before he played in his first game with them. Wilson had a disastrous 2022 season, throwing 16 touchdown passes with 11 interceptions and having a career-low passer rating of 84.4 for a 5-12 team. Wilson has been much better in his first season under Payton, throwing 26 touchdowns with eight interceptions and having a passer rating of 98.0. But the Broncos still have a losing record after dropping three of their last four games and Payton has grown weary of a quarterback who will have made a total of $124 million from Denver if he ends up being released by March. “This one is pretty much as bad as it gets,’’ Fitzgerald said of deals that have been done in NFL history. “The contract that might come close is whatever happens with Deshaun Watson in Cleveland (a fully guaranteed five-year, $230 million deal signed in 2022). But to pay (Wilson $124 million) for two years of service when your team basically is a losing team both seasons basically kills you (on the cap), not to mention everything you gave up.” In terms of a trade, Fitzgerald said it might be the worst in the NFL since “Minnesota trading for Herschel Walker and giving up all those picks to Dallas” in 1989. In terms of money being paid to Wilson, Fitzgerald said it makes it potentially even worse. “With the amount of dead money over a two-year period, I’d say it’s one of the biggest missteps, probably the biggest (in NFL history),’’ he said. A tiny silver lining is whatever Wilson might make for another team in 2024 would be offset and paid to Denver. However, Fitzgerald expects Wilson would look to sign for the minimum of $1.21 million in 2024 while seeking a second year on a deal in which he potentially could earn more than $20 million in 2025. “His value is less than $39 million (in 2024), so why would a team pay him $20 million (in 2024) for money that would just go back to Denver and why would Wilson agree to that?’ Fitzgerald said. “It wouldn’t make sense.” Fitzgerald already lists the Broncos as potentially being $18 million over the salary cap in 2024 with Wilson’s $35.4 million number included. If the Broncos instead incur $53 million in dead money on Wilson in 2024, that potentially would put them about $36 million over the cap. However, Fitzgerald sees the Broncos as having a number of players with big contracts that aren’t guaranteed who could be released, traded or have deals restructured. Those players include tackle Garett Bolles ($15.74 million base salary for 2024), safety Justin Simmons ($14.5 million), wide receivers Courtland Sutton ($13 million) and Tim Patrick ($9.5 million) and defensive tackle D.J. Jones ($9.49 million). In the meantime, the Broncos will press on with Stidham as their quarterback while also thinking about Wilson. “I love Russ,’’ said guard Quinn Meinerz. “I’m proud of how he’s handled this situation. This is a wild situation. It’s been great to play with him and share a lot of great memories with him.” Broncos offensive coordinator Joe Lombardi, who said he first heard from Payton about the move Tuesday, said Thursday it’s a “tough situation” and Wilson is “obviously disappointed.” But Lombardi is proud of him handling it like a “consummate pro.” “I’m sure it’s tough mentally but he’s handling it like a pro, with his head up, always positive,’’ said center Lloyd Cushenberry. “But we still have a job to do these next two games.” After that, barring an unexpected trip to the playoffs, the waiting game will begin. And soon after the new league year begins March 13, Wilson likely will be on another team. |Year||Age||Base salary||Prorated bonus||Roster bonus||Guaranteed||Cap number||Dead money| |2022||34||$2 million||$10 million||$5 million||$7 million||$17 million| |2023||35||$8 million||$14 million||$8 million||$22 million||$107 million| |2024||36||$17 million||$18.4 million||$17 million||$35.4 million||$85 million| |2025||37||$37 million||$18.4 million||$55.4 million||$49.6 million| |2026||38||$40 million||$18.4 million||$58.4 million||$31.2 million| |2027||39||$44 million||$8.4 million||$1 million||$53.4 million||$12.8 million| |2028||40||$50 million||$4.4 million||$54.4 million||$4.4 million| |Total||$198 million||$92 million||$6 million||$32 million||$296 million|
